Let’s KNOWLet’s KNOWStarter
! See the above pictures and tick (3) the activities that need water.
! Where does water come from?
Water is essential for life. About 70% of earth's surface is covered with water. 
Most of our body weight is due to water. Aquatic life would not have been 
possible without water. Plants need water to grow. Water helps our body to 
digest food, transport the nutrients and excrete wastes as urine and sweat We 
may fall ill due to shortage of water in our body. This condition of water 
shortage in our body is called dehydration.
Only about 2.59% of the water on the earth is fit for drinking. The rest 
is salty water which can not be used for drinking.
You 
 KnowMust 
(Knowledge)Water for LivingUnit–V : Our Environment14Environmental Studies-4106

Sources of WaterNo living being can survive without water. We get water from many sources, some 
of sources are given below–
1. 
Rain– Rain is the main source of water. It is the purest form of water. 
However, it gets polluted due to pollutants present in the air. When rain falls, 
water gets collected in the water bodies like sewers, lakes, ponds and oceans. 
It also seeps through the soil and accumulates underground as groundwater.
2. 
Rivers– Water is present in frozen form in glaciers high up in the mountains. 
Rivers originate when the ice in glaciers melts due to sun's heat. Most of the 
rivers flow into the seas or oceans. 
Ganga originates from Gangotri and Yamuna originates from 
Yamunotri glacier.
You 
 KnowMust 
(Knowledge)3. 
Ponds and Lakes– Rain water also collects into ponds and lake. A pond is a 
small body of water surrounded by land. A lake is a larger body of water than 
a pond. Water in lakes and ponds contains several impurities and germs. So, it 
is not safe for drinking. However, it is used for many other purposes. Even 
animals drink it and wade through it during summers to stay coof.
4. 
Oceans and Seas– A sea is a very large water body while an ocean is larger 
than a sea. About 97 percent of the total water on earth is present in seas and 
oceans. But, this water can not be used for drinking because it is very salty.
Underground WaterThe rainwater that seeps down into the soil and is stored there is called 
underground water. The underground water comes up to the surface at many 
places as natural springs. Oasis in deserts are formed by underground water.
For human use the underground water is drawn out with the help of wells, tube 
wells and hand pumps etc.
Earth is called the 'Blue Planet'.
You 
 KnowMust 
(Knowledge)Environmental Studies-4107

Water ConservationCareful use of water is called water conservation. The increase in population has 
led to scarcity of water. So, it is important to conserve water. Dams, reservoirs and 
canals are built to conserve water.
In order to conserve water, it is important to use water carefully and avoid its 
wastage. Some of the ways in which we can conserve water are–
! Taps should be turned off after usage.
! All leaking pipes and taps should be mended. 
! A mug and water should be used for brushing teeth instead of running tap.
! The leftover water in bottles should be emptied in potted plants.
! Mug and bucket should be used for cleaning car, instead of a hose pipe.
! We should bathe with a bucket and mug instead of a shower.
! Gardeners should use water cans to water the plants.
! Rain water should be collected in tanks and used for cleaning and gardening 
purposes.
Ÿ Dehydration 
– 
shortage of water in the body.
Ÿ Pollutants 
– 
harmful substances.
Ÿ Accumulates

Collects.

Ÿ Water is precious. It should be handled carefully.

Environmental Studies-4111

Let’s KNOWLet’s KNOWStarterWaste ManagementUnit–V : Our Environment15Garbage is any material that is of no use for us and can be thrown away as 
waste. It could be in solid or liquid form. There are many different kinds of 
wastes that are produced and thrown away every day e.g. plastic cans, 
polythene bags, vegetable peels, old shoes, old medicines, torn clothes, dry 
leaves etc.
If all these wastes are thrown around in the surroundings, it will create a foul 
smell. It will also attract flies, mosquitoes and other insects which cause 
diseases such as diarrhoea, typhoid, dysentery, malaria, plague etc.
We need to manage our waste properly otherwise we would have garbage 
lying here and there.
! What are the children doing in the above pictures?
! What is the difference between the two pictures?
! Can you define garbage?
Environmental Studies-4112

There are mainly two kinds of wastes–
 (i) Biodegradable and 
(ii) 
Non-biodegradableKinds of WastesWays of Disposal of WasteThe main ways of disposal of waste are–
1. Burning of garbage– We mostly pile the 
garbage and burn it. In cities, solid wastes 
(especially medical waste) are burnt in big 
furnaces called incinerators. This method is 
called incineration. It does not allow insects 
and germs to breed. If also does not create 
any foul smell. However, it causes air 
pollution due to release of toxins and smoke into the air.
2. Open dumping– In this method, the waste is 
taken to places far away from the city and thrown 
into the open to allow it to decompose with the 
action of air, water and sunlight. This method is 
harmful because the dumping area becomes a 
breeding ground for insects and germs. In such 
surroundings, diseases spread very fast.
Biodegradable Wastes1. They decompose or decay easily.
2. They become a part of the soil.
3. Example of such wastes are– 
waste food, paper, vegetable 
peels, dry leaves, animal excreta 
etc.
1. They do not decompose easily.
2. They do not become a part of the 
soil.
3. Example of such wastes are– 
plastics, glass, metals, polythene 
bags etc.
Non- biodegradable WastesIt is very important to separate different types of wastes at home before the 
garbage collector comes to collect the garbage.
Environmental Studies-4113

Waste ManagementDisposing waste is a big problem in most cities and towns nowadays because there 
is not enough space for making dumping grounds, land fills or compost pits etc. 
Therefore, it is important to find a better solution to manage our waste.
If we behave responsibly, waste produced by us can be reduced. The best way to 
manage waste is to follow the 4 R's concept– 
The 4 R's stand for – Refuse, Reduce, Reuse and Recycle.
1. 
Refuse– Refuse simply means to say 'No'. Try to refuse one time use products 
like disposable cups, plates, bottles, straws and other things. Instead, find 
reusable alternatives.
 
Refusing one time use products helps in reducing a lot of waste.
2. 
Reduce– We should reduce the amount of garbage we produce. Some ways 
to reduce wastes are—
! 
Avoid buying things with lots of packaging materials.
! 
Avoid buying throw away products like plastic cups, glasses and tins. 
Use washable cups and plastics 
3. Land filling– In this method, big and deep pits 
called land fills are dug outside cities and the 
waste picked up by municipality trucks is 
dumped into these land fills. When these pits 
are filled, they are covered with soil. This 
method is a better way of disposing solid wasted 
as—
! The waste decomposes in the landfills and becomes a part of the soil.
! It does not provide any breeding ground for insects and germs.
! It does not create any foul smell.
4. Composting– In villages, most of the waste produced is biodegradable. To 
dispose this, people make deep pits in the 
ground. The garbage (biodegradable) is 
dumped into these pits and they are covered 
with soil. After sometime, this waste turns into 
manure. Farmers use this manure in their 
fields. This method of waste disposal is known 
as composting. It is a very good method of 
waste disposal.
Environmental Studies-4114

! 
Buy things only if needed.
3. 
Reuse– Reuse means to use things again rather than throwing them. It can be 
done in many ways–
! 
Reuse plastic or glass bottles, jars and containers after they are empty.
! 
Reuse gift wrapping paper to wrap another gift.
! 
Use old clothes for dusting and cleaning.
! 
Use old papers, cartons, pencil shavings and such other wastes to 
create beautiful art and craft material.
! 
Donate old story-books and text-books to a library.
! 
Donate your clothes which are not in use for you now.
4. 
Recycle– Recycling is the process of converting used items into raw materials 
and making new products again.
! 
Paper is recycled to make new paper.
! 
Soft drink cans are crushed and melted to make new cans.
! 
Broken glass pieces are recycled to make new glass containers and jars. 
! 
Metals can be recycled again and again.
Benefits of Recycling
! It reduces waste sent to landfills.
! It prevents pollution.
! It conserves natural resources.
! It creates jobs, producing economic benefits.
By following the 4R's concept of waste management, we can save a lot of money, 
natural resources and our environment.
! Dispose off 
– To get rid of something that is of no more use for us.
! Garbage dump 
– A place where waste is emptied. 
! Incinerator 
– A big container, closed on all sides for burning waste at 
high temperature.
! Compost 
– Decayed matter which is good for soil.
Key termsKey termsKey termsEnvironmental Studies-4115

Ÿ

Ÿ

Ÿ

filling and composting .
Ÿ 
The best way to manage waste is to follow the golden rule of four R's.
Ÿ
